snippet.textDisplay: I like your intelligent comments Chris Stuckman.  Very insightful..  Very well written, which, to your defense, not everything in the new trilogy was.  Personally, I would give the Rise of Skywalker a higher grade and give The Last Jedi the lowest grade of any of the movies.... even Solo wasn't that bad.  The real reason Solo tanked was not because it was bad, but because star wars fans were protesting how they were treated after criticizing the Last Jedi!  Like you said, "I'd like to see reactions to this movie 20 years from now".... I took the Force ghost of Luke catching the light saber as a TOTAL apology to the fans.  Really the only puzzle piece that didn't fit was The Last Jedi.... and even with The Last Jedi, I have to admit the murder of Snoke was pretty cool... (and ensuing fight scene).... All in all I think they took a 4 hour movie and cut way too much... they should have left everything in and done a 10 min intermission after 2 hours to get snacks or something in the theater.... and what happened to the Venator Star Destroyer we see in the trailers come out of hyperspace in that final battle?  I thought that was really cool... VERY sorry that didn't make it.....  Also, I have to give my reasoning why I think Episode II is better than you do : Boba Fett.... by far my all time favorite character ever.  We got to see his origins, what Slave I could really do.... and why he was so usually cold and calm, but HATED Jedi.... irrationally... it wasn't "just because"...  but again to your point.. at least even the prequels have "cohesiveness"....  it was very nice to see Dennis Lawson in the movie even for 10 seconds (Wedge)... Star Wars  is alive and well with games and comics... always will have new novels and new stories... and I so wish I had Disney plus to see the Mandalorian... all is never lost!

snippet.textDisplay: Chris, I completely agree with you, but, sadly, there was NO WAY that anyone directly associated with this movie (or any of these films since 1999) was going to fully succeed or be commended due to our divided, critical society and the ability of every single crazy, bitter person to have a platform to complain.   The fact is that we've "been chasing", or wanting to capture the pure, simple joy, that the OT gave people since 1983, but it will NEVER be able to happen again, because our world (and the way we perceive things), for better or worse, has changed.   Yeah, this film was busy, messy and convaluted (and, technically, not a well made film by any means, tbh, not to mention that these last 3 films had little or no linear connection whatsoever for obvious reasons), but all of these films were ONLY made in the first place to be entertained and to be enjoyed (nothing more, nothing less), and I think people as a whole have forgotten that.....

snippet.textDisplay:
You’re right, Chris. There are many reasons why the trilogy was a wasted opportunity. Their biggest mistake was not having J.J. Abrams do the whole thing. The thing about consistency is that the best way to have it is to have the same person at the helm. George Lucas was behind every Star Wars trilogy film until Force Awakens. That’s consistency.

Rian Johnson didn’t understand that his job was to let the story carry on, not flip it on its head. I honestly think he didn’t like The Force Awakens and what J.J. was doing. Guess what, Rian, deal with it. The Last Jedi was a film made out of spite, and I can never forgive Mr. Johnson for that. He may be a fine director, but that simply will not do.

The thing about Star Wars is that every little bit of lore matters. Things can’t simply be thrown away. I don’t think he understood what making a Star Wars film truly meant. Nobody is probably going to read this comment because it’s so long, but I just wanted to get this off my chest. The Rise of Skywalker really showed the damage that The Last Jedi did.

All that being said, having a clear roadmap would’ve prevented every single one of these problems in the first place. What a waste. It’s sad really.

snippet.textDisplay: I agree with you Chris. This movie didn't make me necessarily angry like The Last Jedi did, but in a way I was disappointed. For me personally, I really liked the characters in this trilogy especially Rey, Ben, Finn, and Poe. However, I can understand why people don't like them very much and the loss of potential I think they face between episodes 8 and 9. As cheesy and predictable as it would be, I would of preferred Ben and Rey becoming a thing and having kids who would carry on the Skywalker name. Rey would of had an 'actual' family that way and Ben could just focus on raising and loving his kids to not fall down the path he did. I don't know, I just agree with you that it was kind of ridiculous that they kissed and then he just died like that. Someone said they saw the perfect ending as Rey and Ben looking at the two suns while ghost Leia, Luke, and Han stood behind them. I agree that would of been a better ending, especially if Rey was holding Anakin's lightsaber to honor his memory. Idk, like I said, I wasn't mad...just wish there was something more :/

snippet.textDisplay:
I agree that the prequels had more of a roadmap than the sequels. However, the sequel storyline still makes more sense. The prequels were all over the place, except with ROTS and don't explain why plot events happen. They also seem to prepare for something and don't deliver.

TPM - why did the Trade Federation blockade and invade Naboo? Sure, they did it because Darth Sidious told them too but there should have been another reason that the good guys, who are ignorant of Sidious's involvement, can believe. Then Palpatine becomes Supreme Chancellor so he can help fix the problem, but doesn't end up doing anything.

AOTC - why was there a Separatist movement? Again, no reason for the bad guys' motives. We also don't see anyone involved in the movement except the TF and the Geonisians. What was the wholw deal with the assassin getting their poison from Kamino? I get that Sidious wanted to lead the Jedi there but then after that, there's no further pursuing of this mystery about the poison. And what's the deal with this Jedi that supposedly commisioned the creation of the clones? There's nothing further said about him. This movie is the worst Star Wars. The plot is all over the place and there are no really memorable moments. TPM at least had the best lightsaber duel and podracing.

The problems people have with this latest film are mostly about assumptions (which are probably correct) of fixing the issues with TLJ to get the story back on course. They're problems that are external to the movie itself. If you didn't know that they were all made by different writers, would you criticise the sequel movies as much?

snippet.textDisplay:
You know, for a split second I thought they had had a good idea for a closure.


That smart idea I though they had for a moment was, when Flinn talked with that chick and realised a lot of stormtroopers were ready to mutiny, I wanted so bad for them to end up infiltrating the command fleet, take control of the comm center and broadcast a message using the captain stormtrooper badge they got their hands on and have half the empire troopers join the resistance and end the First/Last Order with the rebel fleet in that last battle.
That would have been neat, make sense, being smart and satisfying. Instead, we got dumb, appaling and just plain disapointing.


Intead we had countless lightly armored civilian ships coming out of nowhere in a clear blue sky to face countless heavily armed star destroyers somehow stupidly locked in place since they need someone to tell them where UP is (because obviously we need the empire to be increasingly stupid and incompetent everytime we meet them), otherwise they would have some credibility as villains! Meh!
AND where did all the cosmic storms, magnetic fields and lightning shit go? The place was supposed to be so hard to reach that youd needed secret Sith tech to do it!

Ending with first trilogy ending the Jedi Order, with the second Trilogy ending the Sith Order, then with the last Trilogy with every regular people (starting again with Flinn) awakening to the Force would have been also a good logical outcome, the end of elitism (destroy the midichlorian trope shit) and make the galaxy full of potential new heroes again). A new, new hope!

Another point: didn't they think a good choreographer was needed to make a good lightsaber battle scene? Seing the best fighters in the galaxy fight at the level of 6 yo kids playing Jedi was sad. Since lightsaber duels is a real world thing now, they could at least have trained their actors a bit better. Such lack of commitment is really telling...

snippet.textDisplay:
this review gave me some good thoughts.
What Marvel did really good with their biggest franchise? They made a big arch with a straightforward story leading from first Iron Man up to last Avengers and secured it with a bunch of "character-developing" movies starting from Incredible Hulk and so on.
This 7-9 trilogy is underdeveloped. I liked the arch "how this war works" in 8th episode when Finn arrived at this casino planet. Like where did Republic and Empire get their weapons in such amounts? But this line could have been a spin-off instead of a Han Solo film. This new trilogy is rushed and somewhat full of unnecessary lines and arches where the main characters didn't get the development they need for the story to evolve. This is what the second part for usually.
9th episode feels like "we need to answer as many questions as possible because 8th episode was full of bullshit for the most part".

snippet.textDisplay: I totally agree the trilogy is a mess. But I really don't think it's because they listened to the fans! I really have no idea how anyone gets this idea. I really think it's the other way around. They wanted to subvert expectations so hard, e.g. with Snoke that they ended up with a big frankenstein, in which in the end no piece fits to the others anymore. I really loved the stand alone movies, both Rogue One and Solo. It's kind of hilarious they are not making more of those because the trilogy upset the fans. The fans didn't go see Solo because they were upset by the Last Jedi (and because it was a marketing catastrophy) and the conclusion is, no more stand alones for the time being. That's how Disney is running Star Wars and that's how they listen to the fans.

snippet.textDisplay: George Lucas should never be in total control, but Star Wars was his baby. He understood it, and more importantly, he cared about it. They should have taken his treatments. (Or just looked at the EU.) I think JJ took a yeoman's attitude, where it was just another job. I think Roundhead Rian actually wanted to tear it down, to "subvert" it, to hurt people who cared about Star Wars. And I think Kathleen Kennedy trying to inject her feminism poisoned the well from the very start, where the franchise is less important than her own ego/ideology. No matter what happened, they should have had 1 vision for the trilogy. Instead, they did each movie in a vacuum. And that is the greatest failure of Disney Star Wars. As much as I hate the zombifying of nostalgic franchises for the creatively bankrupt studios to leech off, it could have worked. People liked The Force Awakens, even if it wasn't "special". Disney has no one to blame but Kathleen Kennedy, for bungling the execution. Rian was the bad actor who destroyed, not Star Wars, but Disney Star Wars. And Kennedy let him do it.

snippet.textDisplay:
...Are people forgetting that Palpatine was cloned like five billion times in the old EU, which was considered canon until Disney's ownership?
Also, Starkiller from Force Unleashed was a lot more overpowered than Rey and nobody complained, despite that he NEVER got an explanation for it. The Yuuzhon Vong were a blatant ripoff of Aliens and Borg. Chewy died by getting crushed by an entire planet. And the old story very much contained the overarching idea that neither dark nor light could ever defeat the other, which was pretty depressing.
And I guess people preferred the picturesque Luke from that canon, who never really faced any threat he couldn't deal with, making it an unrealistic yawnfest.
I'll gladly take the disgruntled old man who then overcomes his fear because that's a much more powerful message. And actually has character development as opposed to stagnation.
Oh and by the way, Yoda was the exact same way when first approached by Luke, until he got annoyed enough by Obi Wan to train him anyway.
Even the way Luke dies is reminiscent of how Yoda and Obi Wan both did.
A lot of the elements being conveyed are very consistent with those conveyed in the past, or even convey a bit more thought in some cases.
I understand people got attached to the characters but holding that bias as judgment against Disney, when the truth is that many of those same aspects have existed long before their ownership, is pretty silly.

Don't get me wrong, the films aren't perfect but the old ones weren't either and were often just as flawed. You've got to take off the nostalgia goggles if you're going to fairly assess something.
I mean, did everyone magically forget all the controversy regarding the production of the previous trilogies?
Lucas was no angel. Harrison Ford regularly questioned his decisions and stuck up for other actors.
Steven Spielberg helped round that out as he had more experience and a generally better sense for direction.
The prequels had Lucas solely at the helm and lost a lot of people because of it.
That's the whole reason why the original actors refused his pitch but accepted Disney's.
It was that bad.
And when he came to terms with it, that was ultimately why he sold the rights in the first place.

I can't help feeling that a lot of the present hate of the new and extreme favoritism shown toward the old is the result of some pretty severe cherry picking.
And even if people still don't like it even knowing all of that, at least carry that same analysis into other aspects too.
Otherwise it just falls flat on its face.

snippet.textDisplay:
Nooo, the Internet has gotten to you. I can see why on paper this movie has problems, but I can’t understand how someone who liked The Force Awakens wouldn’t have a comparably good time watching The Rise of Skywalker. Ep 9 is a fun adventure that made me cry, laugh, fist pump, and cheer.

This video isn’t a review of episode nine, it’s a realization that Disney didn’t plan things out like they should have. That is true, but it’s not ep 9’s fault – ep 9 succeeds as well as could’ve been hoped given Disney and ep 8’s poor set up.
If you look at just the film itself, it is a really fun experience, there’s witty banter, characters with chemistry, fun action sequences, interesting developments and revelations.

Like what you were saying about some of the prequels, once you except that they are not what you hoped and instead judge them for what they are, you start to have a much better time watching them. Sure it stinks that it had missed opportunities, but the experience itself is still fun and enjoyable for episode nine.

snippet.textDisplay:
The Disney trilogy and their diminishing returns are actually a living example of the entire franchise when you sit back and think about it. The Disney trilogy was popular, way less popular, then abysmal - in order. The law of diminishing returns.

Now think about the entire franchise...

The original trilogy (Episode IV, V, VI) - Superb. Near flawless. So well received. Created mass hysteria and hype and love for that universe.

The prequel trilogy (Episode I, II, III) - A lot of hype going in due to length of time between. Hopes dashed right off the bat with Episode I. Episode II really fell flat. Kinda restored with Episode III (the best of the prequel trilogy). Overall, people just "like" this trilogy. Not as well received as the original trilogy.

The Disney trilogy (Episode VII, VIII, IX) - Again the hype going in was massive. First installment makes bank and then some. High expectations. Episode VIII completely took the franchise right off the fucking rails. Totally. So divisive it was palpable and you could almost touch the hatred. Fans get blamed for their "vision"/agenda not being accepted. Name calling ensues. Fan blaming again. The male demographic almost exclusively being told "this wasn't made for you". Men respond in kind by staying away in droves. Episode IX on track to make even less than Episode VIII. The law of diminishing returns. The worst received trilogy of the three we were given. People now like the prequel trilogy more than they had previously as a result.

Even the trilogies themselves were the classic example.

This isn't Star Wars fatigue. This is people rejecting shit story, shit characters, and shit agendas. They weren't all over the prequel trilogy, but they took to it begrudgingly. The Disney trilogy only made massive money right off the bat because of curiosity. People were curious where Disney would and could take the lore. They had the MCU and were killing it at the box office, so how could they not with the Star Wars franchise that already had a worldwide built in audience? Well, they found a way. They ruined in 3 movies and 5 years what took almost 40 years and 6 movies to create. They more or less shat all over the first 6 installments and arcs and characters.

Disney, moreso Kathleen Kennedy, strangled their own Golden Goose.

Episode VIII completely took the franchise right off the fucking rails.  Totally.  So divisive it was palpable and you could almost touch the hatred.  Fans get blamed for their "vision"/agenda not being accepted.  Name calling ensues.  Fan blaming again.  The male demographic almost exclusively being told "this wasn't made for you".  Men respond in kind by staying away in droves.  Episode IX on track to make even less than Episode VIII.  The law of diminishing returns.  The worst received trilogy of the three we were given.  People now like the prequel trilogy more than they had previously as a result.

Even the trilogies themselves were the classic example.

This isn't Star Wars fatigue.  This is people rejecting shit story, shit characters, and shit agendas.  They weren't all over the prequel trilogy, but they took to it begrudgingly.  The Disney trilogy only made massive money right off the bat because of curiosity.  People were curious where Disney would and could take the lore.  They had the MCU and were killing it at the box office, so how could they not with the Star Wars franchise that already had a worldwide built in audience?  Well, they found a way.  They ruined in 3 movies and 5 years what took almost 40 years and 6 movies to create.  They more or less shat all over the first 6 installments and arcs and characters.

Disney, moreso Kathleen Kennedy, strangled their own Golden Goose.

snippet.textDisplay: Just came from watching it.. wasn't expecting it to be good, I don't think it was awful.. but I'm still pretty disappointed. I was so happy after Episode VII and I also loved seeing the cast happy for being part of this.. but it didn't work in the end and I can understand why everyone involved feels frustrated and tired of the backlash. I'm not a fan of pointing fingers, but if some one is to blame for this is Disney itself.. owning so many IPs will only result in not being able to focus on each as they could.. they were so confident in owning something as massive as Star Wars and the income it would generate, but in the end it's all about the money for them. I love what they did with Marvel but I'm pretty sure that train will crash eventually.. and to be honest, I hope it does, won't be there to watch it though, I'm done with all Disney IPs at this point (Pixar might still do some good stuff but I'm boycotting Disney alltogether from now on), Endgame was a competent closure to a big saga, but they broke my heart with Star Wars (far more than the time they broke my heart with Spider-Man), seriously, they can FUCK RIGHT OFF.
